title: Using neologisms to test theories of speech production.
abstractText:
There are two commonly accepted models of speech production in linguistics: the classical view, based on Generative Phonology (eg Chomsky), and exemplar models derived from Experimental Psychology. We will test these two ideas against each other.

In the generative model, we plan our tongue motion based on a set of shared mental objects and rules. It assumes that we are parsimonious with memory, computing on the fly.

Exemplar models assume that people store many different examples of words, remembering more and computing less. You might remember many variants of "dog" from different people, in different circumstances. Similarly, when speaking, you choose among many stored patterns of tongue motion for each word.

Exemplar and generative models make different predictions about the pronunciation of words that you have never spoken before.
Exemplar models predict that examples you hear may affect the way you say things. Classical (generative) models emphasize pre-existing rules and features. A new word would be pronounced in a stable, rule-governed way.  We can distinguish these two models experimentally.

Because the models are very different, if we can disprove one, we may have a substantial impact on our understanding of how the human mind produces language.
